The "Provide for the Common Defense Act of 2013" includes sections on the elimination of sequestration for revised security categories in fiscal years 2014 and 2015, as well as changes to Medicare and Agriculture payment adjustments. The "Provide for the Common Defense Act of 2013" includes sections on capping overall rate of return and reimbursements for crop insurance providers, reducing Federal Crop Insurance Corporation's share of premium, federal retirement contributions, annuity supplement, and the use of Chained Consumer Price Index. It also addresses changes in the index used for Social Security cost-of-living adjustments. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to eliminate adjustments for fiscal years 2014 and 2015 in the revised security category. Discretionary spending limits are also set for these years in the revised security category. For fiscal years 2014 and 2015, the discretionary spending limit for the revised security category is set at $552 billion and $566 billion, respectively. SEC. 201. Adjustments to calculation of Medicare Part B and Part D premiums for high-income beneficiaries. Increase in applicable percentage used to calculate premiums for calendar year 2017 and subsequent years. The applicable percentage used to calculate Medicare Part B and Part D premiums for high-income beneficiaries is increased based on income thresholds. The income thresholds range from more than $85,000 to over $214,000, with corresponding applicable percentages of 40, 55, 70, and 90. Additionally, there is a temporary adjustment to income thresholds for premium calculations until December 31 of the year after 2019. The text discusses amendments to the Social Security Act regarding the inflation adjustment for Medicare premiums. It includes changes to the calculation of premiums based on income thresholds and temporary adjustments until December 31 of the year after 2019. The text discusses amendments to the Social Security Act regarding the inflation adjustment for Medicare premiums, including changes to the calculation of premiums based on income thresholds and temporary adjustments until December 31 of the year after 2019. Such subparagraph shall be deemed to be the 12-month period ending with August of the last year of such period described in paragraph (6). SEC. 202. INCREASE IN PART B DEDUCTIBLE FOR NEW ENROLLEES. Section 1833 of the Social Security Act is amended to increase the deductible for new enrollees under Medicare Part B for the years 2017, 2018, and 2019 by $25 each year. The deductible for new enrollees under Medicare Part B is increased by $25 each year for 2020, 2021, and subsequent years. Subtitle B--Agriculture

SEC. 211. CAP ON OVERALL RATE OF RETURN FOR CROP INSURANCE PROVIDERS.

    Amends the Federal Crop Insurance Act to set a target rate of return of 12.8 percent for all crop insurance companies combined for 2014 and subsequent years.

SEC. 212. CAP ON REIMBURSEMENTS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE AND OPERATING EXPENSES OF CROP INSURANCE PROVIDERS. Section 508(k)(4) of the Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to add an additional cap on reimbursements for administrative and operating costs for the 2014 insurance year, not to exceed $935,000,000. This cap will be adjusted annually based on inflation. The Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to adjust catastrophic risk protection and additional coverage percentages for various crops. The amendments aim to reduce the coverage percentages by specific amounts and include a reasonable reserve. The Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to adjust coverage percentages for different units and plans. The changes involve reducing the percentages by specific amounts for enterprise and whole farm units, area revenue plans, and area yield plans. The Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to adjust coverage percentages for different units and plans, reducing percentages for various plans. Amendments made by this section will apply to contracts after the enactment of this Act, changing the contract change date from 51 to 48. Subtitle C--Federal Retirement

SEC. 221. RETIREMENT CONTRIBUTIONS. Subtitle C--Federal Retirement

SEC. 221. RETIREMENT CONTRIBUTIONS.

Amendment to the Civil Service Retirement System regarding individual contributions for civilian service by an employee or Member. The applicable percentage of basic pay is adjusted for calendar years 2014 and 2015. The text chunk discusses adjustments to retirement contributions for federal employees, with specific percentages outlined for different calendar years. Excess contributions made by certain employees will be deposited into the Postal Service Fund instead of the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The text chunk explains the definition of excess contributions for employees of the United States Postal Service and the Postal Regulatory Commission. It also amends government contributions for federal employees' retirement funds. The text chunk amends individual contributions under the Federal Employees' Retirement System by adjusting the amount to be contributed for periods starting after December 31, 2013. The text chunk amends individual contributions under the Federal Employees' Retirement System by adjusting the applicable percentage for civilian service in calendar years 2014, 2015, and 2016. The text chunk adjusts the applicable percentage for civilian service in calendar years 2014, 2015, and 2016, with an additional 0.4 percentage point for 2015 and maintaining the 2016 percentage for subsequent years. SEC. 222 amends Section 8421(a) of title 5, United States Code to include a new paragraph (4) regarding annuity supplements. It states that no annuity supplement shall be payable for individuals subject to this chapter after December 31, 2013. SEC. 223 addresses the use of the Chained Consumer Price Index. SEC. 223 amends the definition of 'price index' to the Chained Consumer Price Index and specifies its effective date as January 1, 2015. It applies to cost-of-living adjustments under title 5, United States Code. The amendment to the Social Security Act defines the term 'Consumer Price Index' as the Chained Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (C-CPI-U) published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This amendment also applies to pre-1979 law regarding Social Security Act provisions. The amendment to the Social Security Act defines the term 'Consumer Price Index' as the Chained Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (C-CPI-U) published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. It also includes a conforming change to Section 215(i)(4) of the Social Security Act. These amendments will be effective for adjustments after December 2014.
